instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board that gets in S0 state, but no image, chime, backlight and CPU activity (checked with USB stick with LED). Fans do spin (first 3 seconds on, then 3 seconds off, then stays on). Heat sink gets warm (not hot). No visible damage on the board.
S0 rails like <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are good.

Since the CPU doesn't seem to do anything I focused on that:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.77V (should be 1.25V ?)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> = 0.98V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL> = 1.05V

Schematic says <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> should be 1.25V, but I kind of doubt if that is right.

Measured some power-good signals:
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.46V
<SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.33V

All seem fine to me. Not sure what to check next. Kinda looks like a dead CPU to me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message:
"Since the CPU doesn't seem to do anything"
Really???
Board works, as you have USB activity.

"Schematic says <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> should be 1.25V"
VCORE is automatically adjusted, via SVID lines.

Did you test external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message: Dead GPU like all of them would be my guess.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message: Very likely, but easy to confirm disabling GPU into BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message:
With "but no image, chime, backlight and CPU activity " I mean no image, no chime, no backlight, and no CPU activity (so USB stick doesn't flash).

If it would be the GPU, it would at least have backlight, right? 

Checked external video, not nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B S0 state, won't boot
threads.message:
Please post accurate infomation; you are the first interested.

0.77V on VCORE looks like CPU has activity; very strange your case.
It normally stuck on the start voltage of CPU power supply, higher than 1V.
Try known good BIOS, just for test; do not only clean ME of original.

To discard GPU issue, which of course can block the CPU immediately after boot, disable GPU into BIOS.
